page.title: 15HISTORIC HOUSES IN BURY/H'TN
page.content: {BURY MANOR.}Owned originally by the Countess Goda, sister of Edward the Confessor, but in 1085 given by William the Conqueror to the Benedictine monks who farmed the land until the dissolution of the monasteries in 1536. The Lord of the Manor became the Duke of Norfolk, and he occasionally held a Manor Court there mainly to decide on farming rights as the manor land then stretched out as far as Surrey. Then in the 1920's it was bought privately by Londoners who used it as a luxurious weekend cottage. In 1964 it was bought by its present owners the Bury Manor School Trust Committee, who turned it into a Boys Prep. School of about 100 boys. They made several minor changes and some additional buildings were built but the original Manor building has been preserved.
